The overall objective of DRM Programme is to “decrease the risk of natural and man-made hazards to rural and urban livelihoods, and ensure infrastructure and recovery mechanisms in place”.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

Total number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, are in place

Number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, which are gender responsive
total number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM)
number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM) that are effective
Flood Recovery to Resilience Programme, Tajikistan
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Affected households provided with cows and poultry. 2. Vaccination and regular examination of distributed animals conducted. 3. Seeds and fertilizer for household garden production distributed. 4. Tools and fencing for household gardens distributed. 5. Sustainable water supply system constructed. 6. Trainings for existing Water User Association (WUA) on water management provided. 7. Equipment for operation and management of the water system provided. 8. Site design for reallocation site developed 9. Houses for most affected households constructed. 10. Health center in Chubek jamoat repaired. 11. Health center for relocated population at new settlement constructed. 12. Flood and mudflow assessment conducted involving international and local expertise. 13. Hazard management plan developed for Sarichashma watershed. 14. Awareness raising and consultation activities conducted. 15. Hazard warning system established. 16. Technical support on weather forecast provided. 17. Weather data collection equipment installed. 18. Trainings on weather data collection and analysis conducted. 19. Conduction of risk and hazard assessments. 20. Development of jamoat resilience plan.

comment.narrative:
On 12-13 April 2014, due to heavy rains and hailstorm flash floods and mudslides hit several districts of Kulyab zone, south east of Khatlon Province. Namely Hamadoni, Kulyab, Muminobod, Shuroobod and Vose districts were affected. Severely affected areas include Sarichashma Jamoat of Shuroobod district, Tugarak Jamoat of Vose district and Balkhobi Jamoat of Muminobod district. Fifteen people fell victim to the disaster during the first two days. Significant damages have been observed in more than 487 households, livelihoods and local infrastructure, including health and education facilities. Severely affected communities include Sarichashma jamoat of Shuroobod district, where in addition to the 104 families affected, more than 500 head of the cattle has been killed. The affected population of more than 780 people has been relocated to tent camp. Under current component the livelihood support activities are envisaged to restore normal livelihood of those affected.
The current setback to the immediate implementation of the relocation plan is that the Bobo Nosirov site lacks a sustainable water supply. While an existing section of Bobo Nosirov (settled some decades ago) has access to piped water, assessments indicate that the supply is currently insufficient for the additional relocated families. The relocation cannot take place if the families to be moved do not have access to water, making a water supply system a prerequisite for moving families to a safer location. It is foreseen to establish a sustainable water supply for the Bobo Nosirov relocation site. This will involve extension of the existing spring source to handle increased demand through spring development, pumps, pipes, storage facilities and a reticulation system with household meters. The water system will be run through an existing water user association (WUA), with operating costs covered through fees collected based on household water use meters. The Government has already established a site plan

1. One hundred households benefited from cow distribution. 2. One hundred households benefited from poultry distribution. 3. All distributed domestic animals vaccinated and passed regular examination. 4. Seeds, fertilizer, tools and fencing distributed for household garden production. 5. Sustainable water supply system reconstructed. 6. At least one trainings conducted on water management. 7. Appropriate equipment for operation and management of the water system headed over to WUA. 8. At least 15 houses built for the most affected households 9. Site design available for further use by local authorities. 10. One Health center in Chubek Jamoat repaired. 11. One Health center in Bobo Nosirov location constructed. 12. Flood and mudflow assessment report available for further use 13. Hazard management plan developed. 14. (number) of awareness raising and consultation activities conducted. 15. Hazard warning system established and well-functioning. 16. Local authorities have appropriate knowledge on weather forecast. 17. Equipment for weather data collection available 18. Improved capacity of local stakeholders on weather data collection and analysis. 19. Assessments conducted, risk and hazards are identified. 20. Jamoat Resilience plan developed.

1. 101 milk cows have been distributed for affected households. Each household reserve one milk cow. 2. Due to the lack of funds poultry was not procured. 3. All distributed domestic animals vaccinated and passed regular examination. 4. Seeds, fertilizer and tools were distributed for household garden production. 5. Sustainable water supply system reconstructed. 6. Due to the lack of funds training was not conducted. 7. Due to the lack of funds equipment for operation and management of the water system was not procured. 8. Building of 18 houses was contracted and construction was initiated. It is expected that houses will be finalized by the end of 2016. 9. Site design available for further use by local authorities. 10. Health center in Chubek Jamoat repaired. 11. Due to the lack of funds health center in Bobo Nosirov location was not constructed. 12. Report on the flood and mudflow assessment is available. 13. Due to the lack of funds hazard management plan was not developed. 14. Due to the lack of funds awareness raising and consultation activities was not conducted. 15. Due to the lack of funds hazard warning system was not established. 16. Due to the lack of funds local authorities was not trained on weather forecast. 17. Due to the lack of funds equipment for weather data collection was not procured. 18. Due to the lack of funds trainings was not conducted for the local stakeholders on weather data collection and analysis. 19. Assessment of natural hazards with UNOSAT (UNITAR's Operational Satellite Applications Programme) was assessed and risks were identified. 20. Due to the lack of funds Jamoat Resilience plan was not developed.
8. 15 houses
8. 18 houses are under the construction, which will be accomplished and handed over to the flood affected households by the end of 2016.

comment.narrative:
1.1 3,302 (13.2%) IDUs reached by HIV prevention services (2009) 1.2 1.30 IDUs received expanded package of services (substitution therapy and detox) (2008) 1.3 6,539 (52.3%)SWs reached by HIV prevention services (2009) 1.4 6,112 in 16 prisons (61%) prisoners reached with HIV programs (2007) 1.5 861 (2.87%) MSM reached by HIV prevention services (2009) 2.1 5,420 (18%) uniformed staff members reached by HIV prevention services (2005) 2.2 571,336 migrants and vulnerable women reached by peer educators and/or receiving HIV education (including condom distribution) (2007) 2.3 3,000 vulnerable youth reached by HIV prevention programme through YF clinics (2007) 2.4 142,341 young people aged 15-24 in rural areas who are reached by HIV prevention services through peer education (2009) 2.5 3,246,101 condoms distributed to vulnerable groups and general population (2009) 2.6 0.7% schools with at least one teacher who has been trained in participatory life skills based HIV/AIDS education and who taught it during the last academic year (2003) 3.1 97% (24,250/25,000) blood units transferred in the last 12 months that have been adequately screened for HIV according to WHO guidelines or national guidelines (2005) 4.1 160 (15.7%) people with advance HIV infection receiving ARVT (2008) 4.2 25 (25.5%) pregnant women receiving a complete course of ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with approved treatment protocol (2009) 5.1. 5 sentinel surveillance sites performing according to national standard (2007) 6.1 8 institutions to improve prevention and VCT services established and supported (2005) 6.2 5 % of IDU receiving HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling in the period of the last 12 months (2005) 6.3 28.6% of SW receiving HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling in the period of the last 12 months (2006) 6.4 14% of pregnant women receiving HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling (2007)

1.1. 6,133 (24.5%) IDUs reached by HIV prevention s

1.1 12,600 (50.4%) of IDUs reached by HIV prevention services 1.2 700 (2.8%) IDUs reached by opioid substitution therapy, detox therapy 1.3 6,663 (53.3%) of SWs reached by HIV prevention service 1.4 4,500 prisoners reached with HIV programs 1.5 5,000 (20%) MSM reached by HIV prevention services 4.1 2,300 (50%) eligible adults and children currently receiving ART 4.2 140 HIV-positive pregnant women receiving complete course of ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT 4.3 809 (50%) of PLHIV attending HIV services and screening for TB 5.1 4,600 IDUs received HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling in the period of the last 12 months 5.2 3,900 SWs received HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling in the period of the last 12 months 5.3 1,420 MSM received HIV tests, results and post-testing counselling in the period of the last 12 months

By September 2015 the supported SDPs reached 53.5% PWID, 50.8% SWs, 22.9% MSM out of overall target indicators countrywide. Mobile units of AIDS centers also contributed to coverage of the risky groups. Besides, 4905 prisoners had peer-to-peer education and counseling on HIV, STI, ART in 13 closed settings. In one NSEP cumulatively 21 PWID-inmates were covered with harm reduction program and 133 prisoners were under ART; syndrome STI treatment was provided to 574 inmates by end of September 2015. Further, OST sites provided methadone-based therapy to 681 as of September 2015. As of the end of September 2015, 2623 eligible PLWH have been receiving ART countrywide.

independent political entity
Energy - power generation
Approved and funded proposal for national scaling up of the SHP demospilots
Annual amount of governmental incentives allocated to support investment in new SHP plants under the scaleup plan by EOP in USD

comment.narrative: Considering the recommendations and policy advice of the project in 2012 2014 the Government has provided direct investments in SHPPs construction that cumulatively constitutes USD 44 mln for 5 SHPPs The total capacity of the commissioned SHPPs is 1967 kW

description.narrative: Central and local government institutions with enhanced capacities to develop and coordinate SHP projects
staff members from relevant central and local government institutions trained in developing and coordinating SHP projects

comment.narrative: 30 staff members trained by the end of Year 2

In addition to the trainings carried out by the project for the Government representatives during the previous reporting year the capacity assessment of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources staff was conducted It has been revealed that there is a significant gap in the planning of RES projects especially in the financial and economic analysis of the SHPP projects which creates a barrier for adequately managing and coordinating resources expanded for the construction of SHPPs In this regard the project in cooperation with EU Sustainable Energy Programme for Central Asia CASEP and direct involvement of the projects Chief Technical Adviser organized 3days trainings on Creating and managing the SHPP cadastre Business game Practical development of RES projects and Financial and economic analysis of SHPP projects which have helped to increase the capacity of 45 staff of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources and Barki Tojik the national electricity utility company

description.narrative: Formulated approved and enforced implementing rules and regulations IRRs of the new Law for RES that will facilitate actions geared towards the enhancement of the market environment for SHP

Simplified procedures and principles for the licensing and construction of SHP facilities
National REEE Fund

comment.narrative:
RES Law includes a number of provisions to facilitate investment in gridconnected RE projects but they are not operationalized
National REEE Fund

Procedures adopted and enforced by end of Year 1
National REEE Fund setup and is operational by end of Year 2

A permanent interinstitutional working group for the implementation of the law on energy saving and energy efficiency and elaboration of proposals to implement the law has been established Interinstitutional working group has 3 subgroups responsible for i issues related to establishment of Trust Fund for RES and EE ii development of the National Strategy on RES and National energy saving program and iii development of legal acts The group is chaired by the Ministry of energy and water resources
The charter of the Trust Fund has been revised to best meet the current developments in the renewable energy sector and was endorsed by 5 ministries except for the Ministry of Finance The financial part of the trust fund still remains unresolved due to the lack of financial commitments from the main international institutions operating in the country that were considered as the primary source of funds along with the national contributions It has to be mentioned however that the share of the national contribution remains unknown and requires further discussions

description.narrative: Guidebook on technical and policy aspects of SHP project development to be used in all trainings to be delivered by the project
Guidebook on SHP project development

comment.narrative: Guidebook on SHP project development prepared and disseminated by the end of Year 1
Completed

description.narrative: Local manufacturers capable of producing combined electric and biomassfired heating and cooking devices for rural households
of local craft workshops capable of manufacturing and assemblage of simple efficient and lowcost electric heating and cooking devices

comment.narrative: At least 1 local craft workshops by the end of Year 3

A Project study on the viability of producing the combined electrical and biomass fired heating and cooking device indicates that production of the devices locally will not be sustained a Local power supplies of 1 kW will not be sufficient to operate the device reducing its demand and b limited demand for these devices is expected due to the flooding of less expensive Chinese goods The target is to be cancelled based on the recommendations of the MidTerm Review

description.narrative: Local workshops and manufacturers with enhanced capacities to install construct manufacture and repair SHP system equipment and components
Technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared for selected local manufacturers

comment.narrative: 2 technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared by the end of Year 1

The capacities of the local manufacturers Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi to design manufacture construct install and repair the SHP systems are further enhanced The local manufacturers have received additional sets of needed equipment for the production of the SHPPs that include electronic and mechanical tools and equipment
Under the supervision and direct coaching of the technology transfer deliverer the local manufacturers have mastered the production of the portable turbines 2 x 15 kW that were installed and commissioned on a pilot basis Based on this experience the manufacturers have been prepared for the manufacturing construction installation and repair of larger electromechanical equipment for SHPPs Both manufacturers are now able to produce turbines and set into operation SHPPs of ranging capacities from 1 kW to 1000 kW

description.narrative: Pilot SHP operations sustained

Number of PPAs signed for purchase of power from pilot SHP plants by EOP
Number of local business supported in pilot localities

comment.narrative:
At least 2 by the end of Year 3
5 by the end of Year 4

The operation of the two commissioned pilot SHPPs in Burunov and Yazghulom are sustained by regular monitoring and provided technical support to the operators responsible for the operationmaintenance and management of the plants The operators of these plants have been educated through the vocational trainings and have been supplied with the maintenance tools and equipment The SHPP in Yazghulam that provides electricity to the border outpost on the TajikAfghan border is sustained by the technicians serving in the border post The plant in Burunov on the other hand provides electricity to a number of clients including the households and the social and economic facilities and has been connected to the national grid Both SHPPs are operating in a sustainable manner

1 small hydropower plant with 30 kW of installed capacity is constructed and commissioned in Sorvo vilalge of Vahdat district Total of 3 SHPPs with cumulative capacity of 245 kW are constructed and commissioned from the beginning of the project
Manufacturing and construction of 4 small hydropower plants started The total cumulative capacity of the foreseen plants is 475 kW

comment.narrative:
Total of 3 SHPPs have been constructed and commissioned while 4 more SHPPs are in pipeline
The total cumulative capacity of the constructed and commissioned SHPPs is 245 kW that annually generate 1288 MWhyear
The 4 additional SHPPs that are in the pipeline will have a total cumulative installed capacity of 475 kW able to generate 2460 MWhyear of electricity

description.narrative: Technical studies political commitments and institutional framework secured for pilot SHP projects

Feasibility studies
Number of integrated district development
Number of SHP projects in the pipeline

comment.narrative:
FS for 2 sites by end of Year 1 3 sites by end of Year 2 5 sites by end of Year 3
IDDP for 2 districts by end of Year 2 3 districts by end of Year 3
At least 5 further SHP projects identified and construction started without direct project support

The feasibility studies have been completed in the previous reporting period
The IDDPs for 5 districts have been reviewed and updated accordingly
5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1967 kW was constructed by the Government Additionally OSCE has supported the construction of 2 micro SHPPs 10 kW each in Rasht Valley IFC has signed an agreement with the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources for the construction of 18 MW hydropower plant in Zervashan valley The Japan Government funded Livelihoods Improvement in TajikistanAfghanistan Cross border Areas LITACA project implemented by UNDP finances construction of 2 SHPPs in Shurabad and Jilikul districts The electromechanical equipment for these two SHPPs 175 kW and 100 kW will be produced by the local manufacturers supported by the project

description.narrative: Vocational training program for technicians involved in SHP designconstruction and OM
of technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP

comment.narrative: 20 technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP starting from Year 2

The project has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the TajikTechnical University to provide vocational trainings to technicians involved in SHP production Based on the signed MoU the project has helped the university in developing the vocational training modules and provided IT equipment a laptop overhead projector and a screen In August 2014 3day vocational trainings for 18 technicians from Vahdat district and 7 representatives of the Ministries of Energy of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan were held The practical trainings were carried out on the facilities of Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi with which the University has agreements
In September 2014 the OSCE office in Dushanbe has requested the services of the University to educate 15 technicians in Rasht valley

description.narrative: Adapted and enhanced legislative and regulatory framework for smallscale hydropower development in the country
Adopted regulation operationalizing RES Law

comment.narrative: No regulations in support of RES Law
Rules and regulations adopted by end of Year 1

The legislative and regulatory frameworks for small scale hydropower development created in the previous years with the projects support the law on Renewable Energy Sources and the law on Energy efficiency and energy saving have led the Government to adoption of strategic documents in favor of renewable energy development As such the national programme for small hydropower plants construction was revised and the national strategy for the development of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency is being developed The revised national programme that will cover the period of 20152020 will include the small hydro solar and wind energy sources and during the reporting period the programme is being adopted
Adopted sublaws to the law on Renewable Energy Sources also regulate the conditions for the solar and wind energy sources although the project does not directly aim at development of these sources Nevertheless the latest developments of renewables in the country suggest that combined application of renewable sources along with small hydropower would better address the issues with the lack of energy in the rural communities The project has therefore been effective in communicating this message to the government which was endorsed

description.narrative: Enhanced technical and planning knowhow and developed market chain for SHP in Tajikistan
of the total SHP installed cost provided by locally made goods and services

comment.narrative: 50 by the end of Year 4

In line with the developed regulations for SHP development the capacities to produce maintain and operate SHPPs were created through the transfer of technology to beneficiary companies Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi and through educating students at the Technical universities in Dushanbe and Kurgantyube The local manufacturers supported by the project have produced tested and installed portable turbines where the share of locally produced goods and services is estimated at over 50 The companies are now engaged in the production and installation of electromechanical equipment for additional 4 SHPPs
The human capacity of the technicians and experts in SHPP development and management is being built through the project Annually a total of 100 students from the technical universities are taking SHPP courses based on the modules developed with the projects support To date 300 students have been reported to have received these courses at the Tajik Technical University and Kurgantyube Energy Institute

description.narrative: Improved confidence on the technical and economic viability of integrated SHPbased rural development model
No of SHP demospilots incorporating aspects of productive uses and livelihood support for host communities

comment.narrative: At least 5 communityowned SHP projects operate on a sustainable basis and at least 5 additional are under construction by the end of Year 4

Total of 3 communityowned SHPPs Nurofar Yazghulam and Sorvo are operating on sustainable basis and 4 more are under construction Sustainability of the constructed SHPPs is ensured through the introduced management mechanisms fee collection methods capacity building of the operators through trainings and provision of basic equipment Additionally SHPP Nurofar sells excess electricity to the local businesses fuel station dairy shop and the plastic windows production workshop during the summer time based on contractual agreement This measure allows the SHPP to operate on sustainable basis as well as allowing the local businesses to have savings from the electricity bills The national tariff for businesses is 33 dirams per kW 005 USD whereas the SHPP offers a trade off electricity for 25 dirams per kW 0038 USD

description.narrative: National Scalingup Programme of Renewable Energybased Integrated Rural Development
Adopted and financed National Scalingup Program

comment.narrative: Na
Adopted and financed National Scalingup Program by the end of Year 4

Through continuous dialogue and political advice rendered to the government counterparts by the project and the international community operating in the energy sector the Government has and is adopting a number of strategies in the energy sector one of which is the National Strategy for Renewable Energy and corresponding action plans and national programmes The programme and the strategies aim at scalingup renewable energy based integrated rural development
For instance the government has already provided direct investments for SHP construction In 2012 2014 the amount invested by the Government cumulatively constituted USD 44 mln for 5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1967 kW This investment has resulted in covering 1500 households schools hospitals as well as the business facilities and created employment for 200 people in remote rural areas of the country

description.narrative: Project title: Tajikistan Water Supply and Sanitation Project (TajWSS) (phase II)
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1.1. By end of 2014 sanitation plan is discussed and endorsed by the Network 1.2. By Jan. 2015 changes to the sanitation and water quality policies, adopted by the IMCC 1.3. By end of 2015 Law on Water Users Associations revised to clarify their mandate in drinking water supply and sanitation systems operation and management 1.4. By Jan. 2015 relevant stakeholders have increased expertise in advocating on gender and WS&S issues
2.1 Increase in willingness to pay and increased tariff collection rates to 65% by Y2 and 90% by Y4 2.2. The new district will adopt the institutional changes implemented during Phase 1 2.3. Hukumat commits at least 10% investment cost in the selected district 2.4. At least 2 models for disseminating gender knowledge and awareness tested and replicated in target district by Y4
3.1. In 3 villages at least 50% reduction in time to collect water for women and children 3.2. In 3 villages at least a 20% reduction in the monthly rates of diarrhoea by the Y4 3.3. In 3 schools in the targeted villages at least a 10% reduction in school absenteeism (disaggregated by sex)

title.narrative: Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II

description.narrative: Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II

title.narrative: Project Document "Border Management in Northern Afghanistan (BOMNAF II)"
Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II

description.narrative: Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Defence - policy, planning and administration

Output 1: - Number of ABP officers and staff trained. - Number of Border Police Units benefiting from the presence and capacity building activities of Training and Mentoring Team (s). - Number of ABP units benefiting from BOMNAF developed training materials. - Number of Border management infrastructure built, furnished and equipped. - BOMNAF provided facilities and equipment are well maintained and supported - Number of officers stationed at BOMNAF constructed facilities received specialized equipment.
Output 2: - Development of an implementation plan on interagency and cross-border cooperation - Number of field events facilitated and supported. - Number of joint meetings and high level seminars supported between border officials from Afghanistan with their counterpart from Central Asia.
Output 3: - Creation and functionality of the Regional Technical Working Group - Number of joint activities between borderland communities and ABP - Number of joint cross-border workshops, symposia at Border Crossing Points - Number of joint patrolling activities - Adopted conference declaration - Number of regional development and cross-border initiatives supported.

comment.narrative: - Weak capacity and efficiency of ABP on Border Management on Afghanistan’s Northern border. - Weak inter-agency and cross-border communication, cooperation, and coordination between Afghanistan and Central Asia - Weak collaboration between border management agencies with the borderland residents.

1. Up to 300 beneficiaries are trained in Integrated Border Management, and associated subjects, including Transparency, Integrity and Accountability (TIA) 2. At least two Border Police Units (40‐200 personnel at each location), benefited from the presence and capacity building activities of Training and Mentoring Team(s) 3. Training Centre in Mazar-e-Sharif constructed; 4. Construction of the Battalion HQ in Chashmai Tut completed; 5. Renovation of Border Crossing Point- Sheghnan completed (as part of maintenance plan provided to EU facilities); 6. Construction of two Border Crossing Points and one Regional HQ building started and in process. 7. Procurement of specialized equipment for Afghan Border Police is in process. 8. A field event for involving border and customs officials is organized and facilitated. 9. A Regional Technical Working Group (TWG) for border practitioners created. 10. Up to 50 beneficiaries trained in anti‐corruption and integrity, including instruction on professional ethics. 11. Up to 3 community-policing meetings with community and border forces are organized. 12. Up to 350 posters and pamphlets about border crossing, narcotic and trafficking are developed and distributed. 13. Up to 3 community training on DRM are conducted.

Prevention programs for people who inject drugs (PWID) and their partners - 11993 (51.9%) people who inject drug (PWID) reached by prevention services - - 13082 (56.6% of) PWID that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results - 214 needles and syringes distributed per person who injects drugs per year by needle and syringe programs - 232 (64.8% of) individuals receiving Opioid Substitution Therapy who received treatment for at least 6 months - 588 (2.5% of) people who inject drugs reached by opioid substitution therapy -

TB/HIV - 90.4% of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register - 84% of HIV-positive registered TB patients given anti-retroviral therapy during TB treatment - 89% of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care or treatment settings - 28.4% of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period

Prevention programs for people who inject drugs (PWID) and their partners - 12705 (55% of) people who inject drug (PWID) reached by prevention services - - 219 needles and syringes distributed per person who injects drugs per year by needle and syringe programs - 750 (3.2% of) people who inject drugs reached by opioid substitution therapy
Prevention programs for sex workers and their clients - 7755 (55% of) sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services -
Prevention programs for MSM and TGs - 6000 (45% of) MSM reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services -
Treatment, care and support - 3198 (32.6% of) adults and children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV
TB/HIV - 85.4% of HIV-positive registered TB patients given anti-retroviral therapy during TB treatment - 90% of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care or treatment settings - 87% of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period
PMTCT - 41% of HIV-positive pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission
Prevention programs for other vulnerable populations (please specify) - 2750 (55% of) other vulnerable populations reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services (prison inmates)

In second half of 2015 the supported SDPs reached 60% PWID, 46% SWs, 44% MSM out of overall target indicators countrywide. Mobile units of AIDS centers also contributed to coverage of the risky groups. In addition, 5796 prisoners had peer-to-peer education and counseling on HIV, STI, ART in 13 closed settings. In one of the prison Needle Exchange Programme (NSEP) cumulatively 21 PWID-inmates were covered with harm reduction program and 130 prisoners were under ART; syndrome STI treatment was provided to 745 inmates in 2015. Further, OST sites provided methadone-based therapy and detox to 698 as of the end of December 2015. Over 6.4 million condoms, 6.6 million syringes and 291.000 IEC materials were disseminated among targeted key populations in the reporting year.
As of the end of December 2015, 3135 (including 1340 female and children under 15 y. o. 496) eligible PLWH have been receiving ART countrywide. ART was prescribed to 80 (48%) pregnant women to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Out of TB patients 87% registered TB patients were given ART during TB treatment. In addition, 68.5% of HIV positive patients were screened for TB and 84% of newly HIV-positive started IPT during that period.

description.narrative: Within the project support will be provided on strengthening the national capacity on aid coordination
Capacity Building for Disaster Preparedness and Response

title.narrative: Project Document "Strengthening Preparedness and Response Capacities"

description.narrative: The project aims to build the capacities of the Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense in preparedness to disaster response operations
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.1.1 # of round tables conducted. 1.1.2 Roadmap developed. 1.2.1 # of legal documents amended 1.2.2 # of protocols and procedures developed. 2.2.1 Capacity needs assessment conducted. 2.2.2 Recommendations on needs improvement developed. 2.3.1 # of heavy machinery procured. 2.3.2 Separate entity under CoES for O&M of heavy machinery established.

comment.narrative: Situation analysis showed that government lacks of unified emergency preparedness and response system in the country and the preparedness capacity both at central and regional (local) levels are limited. In order to deal with the challenges and capacity gaps mentioned above, the CoES identified the Russian Unified State Emergency Preparedness and Response System as an optimal model for replication. The Decree # 833 as of 31 December 2014, on establishment of a Unified Emergency Preparedness and Response System has been issued, but many relevant secondary legislation, protocols and procedures are not on line with requirements on effective functioning of the unified system. Professional intervention teams will be trained and prepared to fulfil specific roles in carrying out rescue operations and take measures such as (temporary) evacuations when needed. These measures aim at minimizing the loss of life and physical damage as well as the consequences during the onset of a disaster. It is suggested that, after a thorough assessment, the heavy rescue equipment required for debris clearance and rescue works in avalanches and mudflows will be procured. At the same time, as CoES is constrained to budget necessary funds to maintain this equipment as a stand-by capacity, it is suggested to develop a business model for a commercial entity to be developed within COES structure, to allow the equipment to be used on a for-hire basis when the equipment is not needed for emergency operations. By developing an appropriate business and operations plan which enables the proper operation and maintenance of the equipment base so that the equipment will be made immediately available in case of disasters.

1.1.1 At least 2 round tables conducted. 1.1.2 A roadmap developed and establishment of the unified system agreed. 1.2.1 All relevant legal documents amended. 1.2.2 At least 2 protocols and procedures are developed. 2.2.1 Tsentrospas capacity gaps revealed. 2.2.2 Capacity development plan elaborated. 2.3.1 At least 10 heavy rescue machinery procured. 2.3.2 Business plan for establishment of commercial structure for O&M of machinery developed.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

The A2J Project Phase II will continue the successful public information and outreach activities of Phase I, including legal awareness campaigns, TV and radio spots, and capacity development for both state and non-state actors.
